journal-title-group.journal-subtitle: Focusing on Technology Research, Innovation, Demonstration, Insights and Policy Issues for Sustainable Technologies

title-group.article-title: A SWOT-AHP analysis on biodiesel as an alternative future marine fuel

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s), under exclusive licence to Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2023

Springer Nature or its licensor (e.g. a society or other partner) holds exclusive rights to this article under a publishing agreement with the author(s) or other rightsholder(s); author self-archiving of the accepted manuscript version of this article is solely governed by the terms of such publishing agreement and applicable law.
permissions.copyright-holder: The Author(s), under exclusive licence to Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature

sec.p: Alternative fuels especially those produced in a green way are essential for meeting supplying the world's growing energy needs. Biodiesel is becoming more prominent to meet international maritime organization regulations, minimize reliance on fossil fuels, and lessen the rising harmful emissions in the maritime sector. Four different generations have been investigated in the production stage in which a wide range of fuel types have existed including biodiesel, bioethanol, and renewable diesel. To investigate all facets of biodiesel usage as a marine fuel, the SWOT-AHP method is utilized in this paper in which 16 maritime experts with an average of 10.5 years of experience participated. SWOT factors and sub-factors have been developed in light of the literature review focused on biomass and alternative fuels. The AHP method is utilized for data acquisition from specified factors and sub-factors according to their superiority to each other. The analysis demonstrates the main factors ‘PW and sub-factors’ IPW values, and CR values to calculate the local and global rank of factors. Results highlighted that “Opportunity” has the highest prominence among the main factors; however, “Threats” remain at the lowest level. Moreover, “Tax privilege on green and alternative fuels supported by the authorities” (O4) is the one with the highest weight compared to the other sub-factors. Noteworthy energy consumption will be fulfilled in the maritime industry in addition to the development of new-generation biodiesel and other alternative fuels. This paper will be a quite valuable resource for experts, academics, and industry stakeholders to lessen the ambiguity around biodiesel.

notes.title: Copyright comment
notes.p: Springer Nature or its licensor (e.g. a society or other partner) holds exclusive rights to this article under a publishing agreement with the author(s) or other rightsholder(s); author self-archiving of the accepted manuscript version of this article is solely governed by the terms of such publishing agreement and applicable law.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Transportation, luxury lifestyle, significant population growth, and fundamental industry sectors seriously increase the demand for fossil fuels which will cause environmental problems (Rizwanul Fattah et al. 2013). That is why the trend towards alternative fuels is increasing day by day in transportation, industrial fuel use, and electric power generation to reduce the dependence on fossil resources, which have the largest share in the world market, use existing reserves more optimally, and manage the energy crisis as a result of the modern age (Chen et al. 2021; Nanda et al. 2013; Saad et al. 2019; Sarangi et al. 2018). While the policies of the governments have a significant role in the selection of fuel types, the amount of the reserve, the production costs, environmental friendliness, and ease of supply constitute the other noteworthy selection criteria in recent years (IEA 2021). In industrialized nations, the use of biofuels is encouraged to lessen the consequences of global warming, limit the production of other harmful emissions, and decrease the percentage of fossil-based fuels like gasoline and diesel used in transportation. In the transport sector, banning fossil fuels could encourage the use of biofuel-based fuels (REN21 2022). Biofuels are an essential alternative to fossil fuels due to their energy potential, accessibility of raw material sources, and potential for environmental production (Müller et al. 2018; Saad et al. 2019).

The concept of biofuels in the marine industry is new and has not been adequately studied in the literature (Kesieme et al. 2019). Recently, the majority of ship owners and researchers have accelerated the search for alternative fuels (Kass et al. 2018) since greenhouse gas emissions including CO2, CH4, and N2O from total shipping constitute 2.89% of global anthropogenic emissions with 1076 million tons in 2018. These emissions were 977 million tons in 2012 (IMO 2020). That is why the presence of biodiesel is a strong alternative in terms of sulfur, PM, CO2, and SOx emission, (Kass et al. 2018) advantages and also many aspects such as the International Maritime Organization (IMO) regulations, environmental awareness, human health, costs, and sustainability (Müller et al. 2018; Nanda et al. 2013; Kass et al. 2018). Besides, many benefits such as regional development, social structure, agriculture, and security of supply are provided (Rizwanul Fattah et al. 2013). However, the preference for fossil fuels over conventional biomass fuels in developing economies is one of the challenges over biofuels (REN21 2022).

It is one of the fuels that is advised for usage in the maritime sector to achieve the 2030 and 2050 decarbonization targets. However, biofuels have long been utilized in the marine industry because they can be blended with the fossil fuels already used on board, which decreases both the consumption of fossil fuels and greenhouse gas emissions (IEA 2018). The B20 blend is 20% jojoba oil + 80% pure diesel fuel and has a lower heating value than conventional pure diesel oil. This causes low brake thermal efficiency, brake power output, and brake mean effective pressure with high brake-specific fuel consumption. In addition, B20 gives higher CO and CO2 concentrations; however, B20 gives lower NOx concentrations. B20 will be a significant alternative fuel against conventional marine fuels with Carbon Capture and Storage technology (Shehata and Razek 2011). Karthikeyan et al. (2017) have demonstrated through experimentation that the nano-added B20 biodiesel mixture reduces exhaust harmful pollutants. Bioenergy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS) can be the solution to the increased CO and CO2 concentration. BECCS is grabbing recognition as one of the most practical ways to achieve “negative emissions” which aims to lead to a net decrement of atmospheric CO2 through the combined impact of CO2 capture and photosynthesis (Babin et al. 2021). Although the majority of biofuels used in the maritime industry come from sugar, oil, and terpenes these are produced from plants, and animal-based waste oils are quite low in terms of quantity (Kumar and Deswal 2022). In addition to carbon emission reduction, very low or zero sulfur emissions have occurred in both the “Well to tank” and “tank to wake” processes which have a significant impact on maintaining the maritime industry's annual reductions in sulfur limits (IEA 2018). A widespread shift from fossil fuel to biofuel in the marine industry will improve marine fuel quality as well as air quality, the ecological environment, and human health (Kesieme et al. 2019). Several recent studies investigated biodiesel utilization on marine vessels. The combustion processes of the biodiesel blends were analyzed and NOx reductions of blends were compared by Wei et al. (2018). The results showed that as biodiesel mix ratios grew, NOx emissions declined and NO2/NOx gradually climbed because of the drop in in-cylinder temperature. Clume et al. (2019) contributed to the literature by outlining a method for estimating how much biodiesel blend will be used in military ship engines. The findings depicted that fuel consumption rises as the amount of biodiesel in the blend grows to maintain engine performance. Waste cooking oil sourced biodiesel utilization on the marine auxiliary engines and resulting intermediate-volatility organic compound (IVOC) emissions compared to marine gas oil (MGO) usage were investigated by Su et al. (2020). Compared to MGO, biodiesel could decrease IVOC emissions by 50%. Bach et al. (2021) analyzed how the technological convergence with fossil fuels has affected the progress and application of biodiesel and liquid biogas in coastal shipping in Norway. Results demonstrated that even though the availability of fuel and cost are significant obstacles, Norway offers favorable conditions for the development of maritime biofuel markets. Li et al. (2022) performed a techno-economic evaluation of various biofuels for maritime freight transportation. Outcomes demonstrated that different biofuel blends and production methodologies become advantageous in various fields of sustainability.

Utilizing biodiesel in marine diesel engines comes with several difficulties and potential risks, although biodiesel fuel is sustainable and eco-friendly compared to conventional diesel fuel. The tendency to form deposits and sludge (DNV 2020) drying and thickening occurrence, especially in cold weather, high viscosity, atomization, and flow properties (Shehata and Razek 2011) can lead to clogging fuel filters, and injectors, to swell and become brittle of rubber and plastic parts and to damage other engine components that reduce engine performance and increase maintenance costs (DNV 2020; Kass et al. 2022; Kesieme et al. 2019). In addition, biodiesel is less stable and more susceptible to oxidation and bacterial growth (DNV 2020). The low energy density of biodiesel fuel presents another difficulty when using it in conventional marine diesel engines. In other words, more fuel is needed to create the same quantity of energy which leads to increased fuel consumption and higher operating costs for marine diesel engines (Jaichandar and Annamalai 2011).

sec.title: Statistics on biofuels
sec.p:
Overall biofuel production has increased by 56% from 2011 to 2021 (REN21 2022), and there were 146 billion liters of biofuels needed in 2020. According to demand forecasts, this amount will reach 186 billion liter levels with an increase of 28%. Excess production, which is the most crucial component of this increase, is carried out to close the gap that was left as a result of insufficient production during the Covid-19 pandemic process (IEA 2021) that the primary cause of the decline in 2020 (IEA 2021; REN21 2022). The subsequent 5-year growth is roughly 4% when the pandemic process' impact is disregarded. Biofuel prices have climbed by 70% to 150% in the US, Europe, Brazil, and Indonesia during the pandemic process, whereas the price of crude oil has just risen by roughly 40% (IEA 2021). The cost gap between biofuels and fossil-based fuels is shrinking considerably as a result of the rising production costs of fossil fuels (REN21 2022). Biofuel types and production volumes are expressed based on years along with the subsequent scenario in Table 1. Table 1

The USA and Brazil remain the largest centers for biofuels both in terms of demand and production (IEA 2021). Waste, forest products, and other biomass types account for 4.9% of the United States' primary energy use (Müller et al. 2018). Two-thirds of the biomass is derived from solid biomass, mainly including forest products in Europe (Sikkema et al. 2021). In recent times, Asian nations have introduced new regulations governing the usage of biofuels. As proof of this, Indonesia plans to mandate the use of 40% blended biodiesel in 2022. India spends time arranging its policies towards using fuel with 20% bioethanol. In Malaysia, the usage of biodiesel is promoted and also Malaysia is one of the world's leading producers of palm oil (palm oil), which is the main crude stock for biodiesel production (Mekhilef et al. 2011). Asia will overtake Europe in terms of biofuel consumption thanks to all these enhancements. When India's objective of using 20% blended ethanol gasoline is realized as one of its five-year goals, India will become the third largest country in the ethanol market after USA and Brazil. This growth in Asia is expected to continue exponentially in the future. Although there has not been much progress on biofuels in China, one of the top Asian nations for industrial activity, it is anticipated that the country would start to use alternative fuels, including biofuels, to comply with future emission standards. Even though crude oil production only increased by about 40% between 2019 and August 2021, the fundamental nations' biofuel production raised by 70% to 150% during the same period (IEA 2021).

sec.title: Generation of biofuels
sec.p:
The term "biomass" refers to the dead or decomposed biological components of living organisms, particularly those from plants and animals (Saha et al. 2018). Biodiesel, bioethanol, and bio-oils are the primer biofuels these are investigated as 4 different generations (Nanda et al. 2013; Kass et al. 2018; Sarangi et al. 2018). The key driving forces behind this generation are improving the energy and production efficiency of fuel from crops, the opportunity for using non-farm land, carbon–neutral legislation, decreasing fuel-food debate, and easy and affordable applicability (Singh et al. 2020). The diversity and quantity of available raw material sources grow, but the level of manufacturing technological maturity declines throughout the transition first generation to the fourth generation (Lin 2022). Biofuel generations are described with feedstock in Fig. 1.Fig. 1
Biofuel generations (Lin 2022)

sec.title: I. Generation
sec.p: First-generation biofuels are made from primarily human-consumed products such as corn, wheat, sugar cane, etc. (Nanda et al. 2013; Sarangi et al. 2018). In particular, plants and cereals containing sugar cane, sugar beet, or starch are utilized in the traditional bioethanol production stage. Biogas, biodiesel, and bioalcohol production takes place in the I generation production (Saha et al. 2018). Due to first-generation production, bioethanol has become valid for replacement of the gasoline worldwide. The majority of this biofuel has been made from corn grown in the USA and sugarcane in Brazil. For instance, Brazil was in a good position to consider ethanol as a gasoline substitute because it is the world's largest producer of sugar from sugarcane. To reduce oil imports, the government encouraged the redirection of some sugarcane production to produce ethanol instead of gasoline (Goldemberg 2008). Total renewable energy investment in Brazil has increased by 27% to $11.6 billion in 2021 exceeding the previous record-high set in 2008 when the nation's biofuel boom was at its height (REN21 2022).

sec.title: II. Generation
sec.p: Contrary to first-generation production, non-food products that have a minimum impact on arable land are preferred in second-generation production to prevent fuel-food debate because I. generation production makes it difficult for people to access basic need products (Sarangi et al. 2018). The variable costs of existing edible products hinder the sustainability of the production of biofuels. Therefore, lingo-cellulosic raw materials such as wood chips, straw, forestry wastes; waste such as urban solid waste, sewage, and waste oil are preferred during the production phase since these products have low cost and are minimally affected by market fluctuations in which edible products are existed (Çöpür and Kütük 2015; Jagadevan et al. 2018; Lin 2022). Lignocellulose, which is found in the roots and stems of plants, develops a defense mechanism against attacks from the outside environment and gives structural strength to plants (Nanda et al. 2013). Considering worldwide agricultural activities, a significant amount of crop residues is obtained, but low productivity is one of the obstacles of this generation during biofuel production (Mohiddin et al. 2021; Sarangi et al. 2018). Despite the significant biofuel production potential of I. and II. Generation based on agricultural and forest products, it is quite difficult to have a share as large as fossil fuels considering the installed facilities (Jagadevan et al. 2018). It is quite difficult to meet even a small part of the transportation fuel needed with II. Generation biofuel production (Chisti 2007).

sec.title: III. Generation
sec.p: Third-generation biofuel production does not affect people's primary food needs such as the second one. Waste oils and algae are considered the primer biomass (Chisti 2007; Lin 2022; Singh et al. 2020). Especially waste cooking oil and palm oil which have high oil content also algae oil comes to the fore in this generation. The cultivation of algae as raw materials takes place outside of agricultural areas (Saad et al. 2019). Algae mostly consist of lipids and carbohydrates (Chia et al. 2018). Nature is less polluted and high-quality energy is acquired by different algae types which have 30–70% fat content compared to other production generations (Singh et al. 2020). III. Generation production puts it in a very beneficial and important position in this way (Chisti 2007). Algae with micro- and macroscales are also utilized in wastewater treatment for water saving. Moreover, carbon dioxide emission reduction is performed throughout the energy production stage by photosynthesis (Saad et al. 2019). Micro- and macroalgae are noteworthy feedstock in the production of biodiesel biogas and bioethanol (Jagadevan et al. 2018). Although the third-generation production feedstock comes to the forefront of sustainability, obtaining a sufficient amount of feedstock requires significant efforts and costs (Ayoub et al. 2021; Chisti 2007). Genetic and metabolic engineering-based studies in algae biology, in which a lot of work is being performed currently, should be increased to reduce the costs of production (Chisti 2007).

sec.title: IV. Generation
sec.p: A zero carbon economy is intended with the knowledge of other generations and the integration of engineering skills based on synthetic and systems biology in the production of the fourth generation (Jagadevan et al. 2018; Singh et al. 2020). In this process, microorganisms and plants are utilized as feedstock to obtain biofuels by making genetic modifications (Lü et al. 2011; Saha et al. 2018; Singh et al. 2020). The most important factor in the emergence of this type of production, which is still infancy level, is the existence and future of global carbon reduction policies and strategies. Researchers aim to minimize the harmful environmental impact via carbon capture and storage methods (Ale et al. 2019; Kumar et al. 2022; Porwal et al. 2020; Singh et al. 2020) The disposal of residues, effects on human health and the environment are the main concerns in the use of genetically modified algae for biofuel production (Abdullah et al. 2019).

The energy obtained from biomass is stored as biofuels, biogas, and syngas. The diverse sources of biomass utilized for energy generation are based on the by-products of the production of food, fodder, and fiber. Biodiesel is mainly obtained from sunflower, soya, rapeseed, canola, palm, and castor oils among the first-generation bioenergy sources. Lignocellulosic biomass such as straw, wood, and secondary raw materials are the second-generation sources for not only biodiesel production but also biohydrogen, and biomethane. The primary first-generation feedstock types used to produce bioethanol can be listed as cereals, sugar beets, corn, sugar cane, and cassava. Lignocellulosic biomass like straw, wheat stalks, corn stover, and wood, witchgrass, and reed canary grass in the second-generation feedstock category is utilized to produce bioethanol. Biogas can be produced from energy crops (maize, Miscanthus wood), agriculture residues (waste leaves, plant materials), and biodegradable waste material involving sewage using microalgae and macroalgae called third-generation biofuels, biodiesel, aviation fuels, bioethanol, biobutanol, and biohydrogen can be obtained (Gupta et al. 2014). Table 2 indicates the feedstock categories, regions found in the feedstock, and co-products that ensure the catalyst reaction (Chum et al. 2012). Figure 2 shows which type of bioenergy can be produced from which feedstock type.Table 2

Bioenergy outputs regarding different feedstock types (Chum et al. 2012)

The future energy need can be met not only by one generation but also through the merging of generations as environmentally friendly (Singh et al. 2020). The two most common fuels made from biomass are bioethanol and biodiesel concerning Table 1, though potentially there are many other types as well. Bioethanol which has a distinctive smell, a freezing point of − 112 °C, and a boiling point of 78 °C possesses identical physical and chemical characteristics as ethanol and can be produced from various feedstock types (Krishnan et al. 2020). The first-generation renewable feedstock-sourced bioethanol has the largest portion of the production, while second and third generations involving lignocellulosic biomass and macro/microalgae, respectively, ensure a significant advantage regarding generating clean and low-carbon bioethanol (Ayodele et al. 2020; Gray et al. 2006; Ocreto et al. 2021; Susmozas et al. 2020). Bioethanol production from sweet sorghum plants using photosynthesis for providing high carbon assimilation supports this argument (Musa 2016). Since bioethanol production does not affect the food/feed chain, it can be seen as a highly sustainable fuel. However, large-scale production processes involving commercial implementations require high efforts and costs (Balat et al. 2008; Bušić et al. 2018). Recycling applications provided during every stage of bioethanol production can provide the most efficient generation process (Chen et al. 2021). Bioethanol can be used as the primary fuel in vehicles instead of gasoline or a mixture of gasoline-bioethanol can be utilized. The mixture can involve various ratios of bioethanol and gasoline. Most of the global demand is met by 10% ethanol-gasoline blends (E10); however, modest amounts of higher ethanol blends (E15–E85) are also available because of restrictions on the fuel-supply system and vehicle compliance. Brazil is the second largest bioethanol producer and a significant portion of the production is utilized for domestic purposes, either as pure ethanol fuel or combined with gasoline. Anhydrous bioethanol, which typically contains 27% ethanol in gasoline blends, makes up a large portion of the nation's overall bioethanol consumption (Susmozas et al. 2020).

Biodiesel is a notable alternative to fossil fuels which is a non-toxic, biodegradable, inherent lubricant, having a superior flash point (Gebremariam and Marchetti 2018; Moser 2011). The primary feedstock types for the production of biodiesel are edible or non-edible vegetable oils, animal fat, and algae. Biodiesel is produced by utilizing the transesterification process, and the main stages of the transaction contain the feedstock, catalyst, reaction, and separation or purification of the product (Mohiddin et al. 2021; Singh et al. 2020). Biodiesel production from the feedstock types having high oil content requires extra effort in terms of catalyst amount and production stages. Microbial oil-based biodiesel production has the potential to meet all fuel demands however; the delicate working temperature range is an important drawback that holds back this production method. The oil-to-alcohol ratio, water, and FFA quantity, reaction temperature, pressure, and agitation speed all determine how quickly the transesterification reaction occurs. Temperature, the ratio of oil to alcohol, the amount of water and FFA present, the rate of agitation, and the reaction duration are crucial transesterification reaction factors (Venkateswarulu et al. 2014). Furthermore, the lack of marine-grade fuel specifications, cold flow properties; fuel supply, storage, and infrastructure are one of the main issues that should be taken into consideration for biodiesel as marine fuel (Kesieme et al. 2019).

The literature investigation has highlighted a research gap in the investigation of all biodiesel generations and their utilization on marine vessels. This research paper aims to evaluate the beneficial and non-beneficial aspects of biodiesel usage onboard for the achievement of sustainable maritime transportation goals. SWOT-AHP hybrid methodology was employed to assess various facets of biodiesel in the study with the participation of 16 maritime experts having an average of 10.5 years of experience. The findings of the analysis were discussed and compared to the related studies.

sec.title: SWOT analysis
sec.p: In the modern era, strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats (SWOT) analysis is a commonly preferred technique that evaluates the aimed strategies considering determined factors and highlights how to implement the innovations. Particularly SWOT analysis has been carried out to assess the current position of companies or institutions and has been applied to various sectors. Strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats are defined as the main factors in SWOT analysis. Strengths and weaknesses are internal factors that can be controlled by the management. Opportunities and threats, on the other hand, are defined as external factors as they are factors that have little or no controllability. In addition, strengths and opportunities are taken as helpful factors since they support the argument in terms of innovation, rules, and regulations, while weaknesses and threats are called harmful factors since they prevent the action (Sarsby 2016). Helpful factors and existing beneficial aspects can be enhanced, and further opportunities can be evaluated by utilizing the analysis.

SWOT analysis applied in many departments in businesses has also applications in the evaluation of energy resources that are likely to be used in the future. Sub-criteria of the analysis have been determined by considering technological, economic, environmental (Kesieme et al. 2019), technical, policy, and social aspects (Li et al. 2020; Wang et al. 2020). Regarding the main issues listed above, usability, technological development and integration, and operational challenges (Kesieme et al. 2019), the current situation of electrical vehicles involving market potentiality and the business strategy, fuel cost, application of renewable energy sources on vehicles, and the utilization of CNG, methanol, and biofuels on the internal combustion engines is a general concern for the SWOT methodology (Guangul and Chala 2019; Kowalska-Pyzalska et al. 2020; Lee et al. 2021; Li et al. 2020; Suman et al. 2020; Wang et al. 2020). Required policies for ensuring green and sustainable transportation have been evaluated and determined by utilizing the SWOT technique (Guangul and Chala 2019; Kowalska-Pyzalska et al. 2020). For instance, strengths of the solar energy can be listed as being environment friendly, the lifespan of the resource, and low operation costs. The weaknesses and threats can be determined as low efficiency, storage of energy, and recycling costs (Guangul and Chala 2019). For the analysis of renewable energy sources, economic and sociopolitical issues have gained more importance (Wang et al. 2020). When the whole alternative fuels and sources have been evaluated, helpful factors can be listed as the construction of a sustainable transportation network, being an environmentally benign energy source, prevention of global warming, the potential of enhancement of the current infrastructure, a life of source, operation costs, technological enhancements, the potential decrease of the manufacturing and installation costs, ease of usage, driver comfort, and tax privileges (Guangul and Chala 2019; Kowalska-Pyzalska et al. 2020; Lee et al. 2021; Suman et al. 2020). On the other hand, harmful factors can be itemized as low energy density, energy storage costs, low costs of fossil fuels, safety, lack of infrastructure, complicated installation, the difficulty of long-range applications, being out of service in case of power cut (Guangul and Chala 2019; Lee et al. 2021; Suman et al. 2020).

The evaluation of bioenergy generation and types of bioenergy such as bioethanol, biodiesel, and biomethane has been ensured by using SWOT and analytical hierarchy process (AHP) together. By utilizing the combination of these methods analyses of waste cooking oil-based biodiesel, sugarcane, and sweet sorghum-sourced bioethanol, waste briquette, and sawdust briquettes biomass sourced bioenergy have been conducted. The evaluation of biomethane utilization on a vehicle instead of natural gas has also been carried out by using mentioned methods (Barbosa et al. 2022; Catron et al. 2013; D’Adamo et al. 2020; Ferronato et al. 2022; Yu et al. 2022).

For the analysis of biomass, highly efficient production with new generations, experience in the first generations, conformity to safety regulations, low production values, various and rich feedstock types, being a renewable source, and reducing fossil fuel dependency can be taken as the strength. The weaknesses are high installation costs depending on the generation, production, and operation costs, lack of infrastructure, the discrepancy between production and needed areas, lack of maturity, knowledge, and complexity of biofuel production, the low energy efficiency of some generations, lack of demand, the difficulties of the theoretical applications which promises higher efficiencies, low volumetric efficiencies of algae sourced biofuels. The opportunities can be summarized as chances given by the government and companies, tax privileges, support for innovations, accelerating academic and sectoral studies, creating new business areas, market potential, potential to close the energy gap, and high energy efficiency to be achieved with 3rd and 4th generation production. Deforestation, respiratory-related health issues sourced from the production phase, demand increment of forest products, reliance on edible sources for the first generation, uncertainties about future politics, and remarkable decrease in fossil fuel prices are counted as threats. (Barbosa et al. 2022; Catron et al. 2013; Chala et al. 2019; D’Adamo et al. 2020; Gray et al. 2006; Moser 2011; Nanda et al. 2013; Peng et al. 2020; Sarangi et al. 2018; Yu et al. 2022). Health issues involving respiratory problems are linked to endotoxin and fungal exposure among workers in biomass-fired power plants if the required precautions are not taken. Hydrogen sulfide leaks in biogas plants have the potential to be lethal or have serious negative health effects (Chala et al. 2019; Freiberg et al. 2018).

It is suggested that to ensure required elucidating in the various platforms for providing social acceptance and preventing social, technical, and economical obstacles (Gray et al. 2006; Moser 2011; Sarangi et al. 2018; Yu et al. 2022). In addition, raw material costs, which are the most important economic barriers, have the potential to reduce the existence of productivity-enhancing technologies and the decrease in raw material costs (Gebremariam and Marchetti 2018). The determination of the sub-factors of a SWOT analysis of biodiesel can be ensured by evaluating the reports of sector representatives, regulations of IMO, and global environmental policies (Khan et al. 2021). Figure 3 demonstrates the decided sub-factors of the SWOT analysis for this study.Fig. 3
SWOT sub-factors for the evaluation of biodiesel as a marine fuel

sec.title: Analytical hierarchy process
sec.p:
Five criteria for each main factor and a total of twenty criteria are determined based on technological, technical, economic, environmental, sociopolitical, society-related aspects (Li et al. 2020; Wang et al. 2020). To evaluate criteria and to determine their importance degree, the AHP introduced in 1977 by Thomas L. Saaty and is applied in many studies in the fields of education, health, industry, and textile is utilized (Ayrıçay et al. 2017). Table 3 indicates Saaty’s scale which is one of the most utilized methods in the literature to compare criteria.Table 3
Description of Saaty’s scale (Harker and Vargas 1987)
Importance intensity
Definition
Explanation
1
Equal importance
Two activities contribute equally to the objective
3
Weak importance of one over another
Experience and judgment slightly favor one activity over another
5
Essential or strong importance
Experience and judgment strongly favor one activity over another
7
Demonstrated importance
Activity is strongly favored and its dominance is demonstrated in practice
9
Absolute importance
The evidence favoring one activity over another is of the highest possible order of affirmation
2, 4, 6, 8
Intermediate values between the two adjacent judgments
When compromise is needed

At the final stage consistency ratio (CR) is checked, and if the CR is lower than 0.1, the comparison matrix is assumed to be consistent. In Eq. (3), RI represents Random Index which is shown for different matrix dimensions (n) in Table 4.Table 4

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
The investigation of the advantages and disadvantages of biodiesel utilization was ensured by applying the SWOT-AHP method to the findings acquired from surveys and interviews with sixteen different experts which include a marine surveyor, oceangoing chief and second engineer, oceangoing master, marine pilot, project engineer, loading master, and engine superintendent. The range of total experience of experts is between 9 and 24 years and also the average expert experience is 10.5 years in research. The working fields and experiences of each expert are illustrated in Table 5.Table 5
Expert profile in the study

The priority weights (PW) of each were compared based on expert opinions by AHP to identify whether a sub-factor is more important than the other. The significance of each sub-factor in their respective disciplines was then determined using a similar methodology. Internal priority weights (IPW) were calculated by producing the weights of the sub-factors and factors to rank the significance of sub-factors globally. The validity of the analysis was evaluated by calculating the CR values for each factor. The findings of the analysis, which are the PW, IPW, CR, local, and global rankings values, are described in Table 6.Table 6

CR values highlighted in Table 6 are sufficient to ensure the validity of the SWOT-AHP analysis since the threshold of value should be lower than 0.1. The CR parameter of the SWOT main factor was calculated as 0.046 and the CRs of each sub-factor are 0.1, 0.063, 0.013, and 0.022, respectively, these values also verify the analysis by being under the specified limit. The PW was calculated substantially higher for opportunities and also strengths of biodiesel utilization in marine vessels were determined as the second most dominant feature in the analysis. The weight of the threats was computed as closer to the strengths as evidence to this situation Kass et al. (2018) highlight that further research and evaluation is needed about the compatibility of biodiesel on combustion and fuel systems of ship engines since Andersson et al. (2020) state that there is still an ambiguous situation in terms of fuel diversity and availability on biodiesel. Besides these, the weaknesses of biodiesel were ranked at the last spot with a remarkably low weight. These results highlight that biofuel-based efforts create remarkable future opportunities since the majority of experts have currently prioritized decarbonization goals established by the IMO and the European Union for the future shipping industry.

“Tax privilege on green and alternative fuels supported by the authorities” (O4) constitutes the peak with the highest importance among the sub-factors. Kesieme et al. (2019) describe that the predominant way of promoting alternative fuels in maritime transport is provided by tax privilege, exemptions, and state subsidies. Mekhilef et al. (2011) point out that governments in Europe have provided biodiesel subsidies to encourage the production of sustainable energy.

The outputs of the analysis demonstrate that the other high-ranked sub-factors are “Creating alternatives to fossil fuels and revealing new business opportunities” (O3), and “Decarbonization targets of international authorities in 2030 and 2050” (O2). Rizwanul Fattah et al. (2013) determined that replacing the majority mass of fossil fuels with biodiesel will be effective in meeting international targets and removing the negative effects on the environment. Besides, biodiesel will take place in the energy market as one of the alternative energy sources with the fastest growth potential and will create new employment areas. Tan et al. (2021) evaluated biofuels, which can be potentially utilized as a marine fuel, by using techno-economic and life cycle assessment (LCA) analyses. In terms of cost-effectiveness, pyrolysis bio-oil is found as the best for lowering CO2 emissions and this finding promotes the O2 sub-factor of the analysis. Diesel production from biomass and natural gas by the Fischer − Tropsch method is the second strategy for CO2 reduction. This makes biodiesel a significant substitute for fossil fuels and advocates the O3 sub-factor.

“High production efficiency to be achieved in the 3rd and 4th generations” (O1), and “Environmentally friendly and renewable energy” (S3), respectively. Mekhilef et al. (2011) biodiesel is seen as a better option because it is produced in an environmentally friendly and renewable way, although biodiesel provides almost the same technical characteristics as fossil fuels. The environmental effect of biodiesel depends on the production methodology vastly however, in terms of air pollution biodiesel provides transportation with much lower GHG emissions compared to fossil fuels regarding the results of the LCA analysis conducted by Nanaki and Koroneos (2012). In addition, most major engine manufacturers claim that biodiesel is suitable for marine engines and conversion would be done much easier (Mohd Noor et al. 2018).

“Ongoing technological performances on fuel production from biomass” (O5), respectively. Khan et al. (2018) discuss that biodiesel is an undisputed potential source of renewable energy options in the transportation industry since they require less technological advancement than other renewable alternatives with ease of adaptability to already-existing infrastructure systems. However, Kesieme et al. (2019) mention that main engine equipment should be modified to utilize biodiesel since many parameters can affect biodiesel-fueled engine performance such as injection pressure, air–fuel mixture quality, injector nozzle design (Mohd Noor et al. 2018).

In Table 6, the IPW values are the same for (O2) and (O1). However, with a slight difference (in the numbers after the comma), (O2) is ranked higher. The significance of opportunities and strengths has become prominent due to challenging emission reduction targets in the maritime sector. These targets mainly cover the lowering of CO2 that is provided by alternative fuels and renewable energy sources. The experts determined that biodiesel is a usable and environmentally benign alternative fuel for ships to ensure a significant reduction of CO2 emissions. Kesieme et al. (2019) also concluded that current and future environmental regulations can be met by biodiesel.

“Occurrence of various health problems during energy production especially on respiration” (T1) and “Deforestation” (T5) which are the sub-factors of threats, are ranked 6th and 8th in the global, respectively. Khan et al. (2021) point out that advanced biodiesel derived from biomass that humans do not consume as food is preferred. Contrary to the health problems that occur during production, Kesieme et al. (2019) highlighted that the combustion process does not affect human health as much as fossil fuels.

The least important sub-factors determined in the analysis can be listed as “Long payback period with existing technology” (W5), “Incompatibility of the required location and production” (W4), “Initial investment cost, operating and production cost” (W1), “Uncertainty of future policies on biodiesel production” (T4), “High energy efficiency” (S1). These outcomes emphasize that the problems concerning cost, legalization and production processes have been found as solvable regarding expert opinions. When all legislative barriers are removed, Andersson et al. (2020) described that the vast majority of ship-owners prefer the lowest cost of technology.

Bilgili (2021b) conducted benchmarking alternative fuels which have the potential clean usage in marine engines and obtaining in an environmentally friendly way. The ever-developing IMO standards and limitations based on decarbonization, in terms of NOX and SOX reduction strategies, can be easily met by utilizing alternative fuels onboard. (Bilgili 2021a) analyzed and compared the environmental impacts of alternative fuels containing biodiesel throughout their life cycle for the future. Methanol, ammonia, and biodiesel life cycle performances are found as the most unsuitable in alternative fuel groups. Even though this circumstance generally meets sub-factors of all weakness that is quite close to “Low efficiency particularly in the 2nd generation and NOX Emission” (W3). Biodiesel has various effects on human health and ecosystem quality when compared to other alternative fuels. The highest social cost has been spent on LNG among the alternative fuels to minimize the environmental effect caused by emissions through well-to-wake and tank-to-wake processes. In addition, the social cost of biodiesel group fuels approaching 1000 € is at a level that cannot be underestimated in this field. These results support to the sub-factors “Initial investment cost, operating and production cost at last generations” (W1) and “Presence of fossil fuels produced at a lower cost than biodiesel fuels” (T3).

High energy efficiency provided by biodiesel was not detected as an important sub-factor according to experts compared to the opportunities and other strengths. Although many alternative fuels have high energy output, application difficulties can influence the choice of experts. To reduce the fossil fuel dependency, and resulting CO2, various alternative fuels other than biodiesel such as methanol, ammonia, and liquefied natural gas have been considered as a solution. Even though these alternative fuels have significantly lower calorific values (LCVs) compared to diesel fuel, the investments and researchers prioritize them to overcome emission reduction goals. On the other hand, first-generation biodiesel can perform close to diesel fuel during the combustion process, but its production leads to the depletion of cultivated areas and fuel food debates. Second-generation biodiesel has lower efficiency and cannot meet the whole energy demand onboard, although its production process has been ensured from waste products. Initially, it can be used as a blend of diesel fuels, or used in the small-scale generator that meets a lower electrical demand in the vessel. Third-generation biodiesel production has great potential to solve the low-efficiency problem, and the generation of the fuel is not dependent on the consumer products like the first generation. However, the cost of production is too high with the current technology. The production with fourth generation can offer more cost-friendly solutions but it has not been commercialized yet. Kass et al. (2018) highlight that all potential biofuel types have incredibly low sulfur levels, however, each biofuel candidate has different characteristics that will determine which types of marine fuels it can be blended with or replaced. The role of biodiesel fuels is not to replace existing fossil fuels, but rather to create balanced energy policies that can benefit the international marine community and to create green alternative energy for marine applications described by Mohd Noor et al. (2018).

Watanabe et al. (2022) focused on the second generation in which biofuels produced from wood and forest industry residual. It is utilized as a marine fuel, they have a lower environmental impact than fossil fuels, and the lowest climate impacts are acquired by the Fischer–Tropsch production method. Moreover, the highest level of production efficiency is obtained by the fast pyrolysis and hydrothermal liquefaction methods. The effects of climate mitigation have grown together with the experiences and technological developments performed throughout the previous years. In this way “Lack of infrastructure, insufficient and complex production, lack of maturity in especially in new generations” (W2) ranked as a third among sub-factors of weakness will be eliminated in the following years.

In addition to the SWOT-AHP model outputs, the experts highlighted the importance of sustainability and production costs for the utilization of biodiesel on marine vessels to reduce emissions and harmful environmental impacts during interviews. It is also stated that authorities will play a crucial role in fuel taxation of countries, recruitment of the feedstock, production location, and cost. The external dependence on feedstock to produce biodiesel can slow down some countries to make some moves on the legalization issues. On the other hand, countries that demand high taxes for such investments can discourage investors in this field.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The international maritime organization sets out various regulations to reduce harmful emissions such as NOX, SOX, PM, and CO2 from maritime transport. Especially, a movement toward alternative and renewable fuels has started to minimize dependence on fossil fuels and eliminate emissions from ship engines. One of many alternative fuels is biofuels which have acquired popularity as a result of high efficiency from first-generation experience. However, the feedstock source required for first-generation production is generally obtained from arable farmland, which brings about fuel food debates. Second-generation production concentrates on non-edible goods and wastes forest products to eliminate these debates. Studies on the third-generation biofuels production, in which primary feedstock is algae, have grown as a result of the second generation which have not achieved as high levels of efficiency compared to the first generation. The third generation faces several challenges, but the major one is cost and infrastructure. Experts in biofuels are intended to solve all the issues with the fourth generation which is synthetic-based biofuels but the transition to commercial applications has not been completed finished yet.

In this paper, a SWOT analysis is performed to determine all internal and external factors on biodiesel as a future marine fuel. Each factor's sub-factor is developed concerning the literature's energy research, particularly on alternative fuels. AHP approach is utilized to assess how superior each factor and sub-factor are to the others by 16 experts that include a marine surveyor, oceangoing chief and second engineer, oceangoing master, marine pilot, project engineer, loading master, and engine superintendent. Among the factors, “Opportunities” have the greatest significance followed by “Strengths,” “Threats” and “Weaknesses” factors, respectively. The promise of biodiesel as a future marine fuel is highlighted by the fact that opportunities priority weighs as much as the total of all other factors. “Tax privilege on green and alternative fuels supported by the authorities (O4),” “Creating alternatives to fossil fuels and revealing new business opportunities (O3),” “Decarbonization targets of international authorities in 2030 and 2050 (O2),” “Environmentally Friendly and Renewable Energy (S3)” and “Ongoing technological performances on fuel production from biomass (O5)” constitutes the first five ranks, respectively. However, “Long payback period with existing technology (W5),” “Incompatibility of the required location and production (W4), “Lack of infrastructure, insufficient and complex production, lack of maturity especially in new generations (W2), “Deforestation (T4),” and “High energy efficiency (S1)” are the lowest level, respectively, in the current condition.

The limitations of the study can be listed as follows:
The analysis has been conducted regarding the current costs and technology of the maritime sector and biodiesel production facilities. The future increment of the utilization and production of the third and fourth generations was neglected.
Sixteen experts who evaluated biodiesel as the end user was interviewed. The participation of experts who produce or will produce biodiesel as a marine fuel was not provided in this study.

Briefly, biodiesel has significant potential as an alternative fuel for marine applications. Improvement efforts to eliminate existing weaknesses and threats factors and sub-factors in biodiesel will pave the way for their utilization in the future. The applications that will be performed during the process will provide the greatest indication of how much biodiesel will be consumed in comparison to other marine fuels. This paper will be a noteworthy resource for academicians, experts, and stakeholders who will work on alternative fuels. In further studies, the utilization of the different types of bioenergy in marine vessels can be analyzed using various investigation methodologies. Further studies can comprise an analysis with more experts working on the production side of the biodiesel industry, and the investigation of the future projections of third and fourth generations’ usage rate increase and its impact on the maritime industry. The investigation of the other alternative fuels can also be ensured by using a similar or enhanced methodology.

sec.p: No funding.

sec.p: All data collected during this study are included in this published article.

sec.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
